projects.title: Winegrid
projects.subtitle: The Winegrid platform for the company Watgrid
projects.shortDescription: The platform to be developed for Winegrid was quite challenging as it encompassed a complex information architecture which generated a gap with the user's mental model. In order to test and allow common ground of understanding between the team members a hi-fi prototype was made in Adobe XD. This made it easier to guess implementation efforts and the validity of some of the functionalities.

contentBlocks.text: The platform to be developed for Winegrid was quite challenging as it encompassed a complex information architecture which generated a gap with the user's mental model. In order to test and allow common ground of understanding between the team members a hi-fi prototype was made in Adobe XD. This made it easier to guess implementation efforts and the validity of some of the functionalities.

contentBlocks.heading: Product
contentBlocks.text: Watgrid's product, Winegrid, was a very interesting project and I'm very glad I got to be part of it during my master's. It is a groundbreaking technology, with a complex information architecture. They develop and produce sensors to monitor wine production in real time, alongside a SaaS platform to control their devices. I was working as a UX designer, supporting the platform's development team.

contentBlocks.heading: UX Challenges
contentBlocks.text: The fact that it was a company just popping out of start-up status, meant there was still some distance between the engineer's mental model, and that which would make sense for the final users. Also, few of the engineers understood how to produce wine and none of them how a full sized industrial production of wine works. So it was necessary to understand the differences, create a new mental model and reflect this on the platform itself. For about a year this was a work in progress, as the platform was already up and running. I studied, designed and developed, also as new features were being introduced to the platform on a regular basis. Gladly, new investments were made that changed our game.

contentBlocks.heading: Development Challenges
contentBlocks.text: Most notoriously, I designed and developed a selection element that faced a challenged, and of which I am quite satisfied. The user needs to be able to select the daily reading frequency of each sensor, but that can't be more that once every thirty minutes, and it has to be in equal intervals throughout the day. These were technical constraints. The user should also be able to select when the first read of the day was to happen. In order to avoid explaining to the user all the necessary, and to avoid error, it was necessary for the affordance of this element to enforce all of this, and be clear at the same time. So a slider for the frequency was chosen, alongside a scheduler that allowed to select the initial time and view all the other consecutive schedule readings. To further ensure readability, a clarifying human readable sentence was output dynamically with the selection. This was developed in Angular and later translated into Jquery.

image.alt: Screen capture of a frequency selector interface
image.caption: Frequency Selector

contentBlocks.heading: Work in Graphical Design and Marketing
contentBlocks.text: Besides working as a UX Designer, I also supported the marketing team, mostly with graphical design. The branding of the company was also not solidified, so this was a challenging process as well. Most notoriously, I designed a quick guide for users, in a single sheet of A4, to go with every shipped device. It used only iconography, so that translated versions were not necessary, and a QR Code directed for further clarifications, although this was reported as not used. I also produced an instructional video and maintained the website's activity.

projects.title: Banco de Tempo de Santa Maria da Feira
projects.subtitle: Project for Master's dissertation
projects.shortDescription: This project studied the potential contribution of multimedia technology for a timebanking community in Santa Maria da Feira, Portugal. As a proof of concept, two prototypes were developed for a majorly senior community.

contentBlocks.text: This project studied the potential contribution of multimedia technology for a timebanking community in Santa Maria da Feira, Portugal. As a proof of concept, two prototypes were developed for a majorly senior community.

image.alt: Image of Banco de Tempo de Feira
image.caption: Timebank platform prototype

contentBlocks.heading: Collaborative Economy
contentBlocks.text: The Collaborative Economy is a phenomenon of the recent decade, where new and old habits of exchange were developed and re-discovered in the digital realm. Most notoriously - new methods of creating value collaboratively; making use of inert value and sharing goods, services and even time - have created a new highly valued market, challenged policies, and promoted a more sustainable way for people to face their daily challenges. There are also companies that tag along with the promises of social, economic and ecological sustainability, but fail to deliver and end up just exploiting members of their digitally created communities for their own gain.

contentBlocks.heading: Time Banks
contentBlocks.text: In the meantime, there's an idea that has existed far before, and that is used mostly for social rehabilitation and economic self-reliance in smaller communities. We're talking about time-banks, where people exchange their time, valuing everyone's time equally. So an hour from a plumber is as valuable as an hour from a tutoring mathematician. One would request a service and "pay" the person in time-credits, equivalent to the time spent in providing it. And this person will be able to exchange similarly with other members.

contentBlocks.heading: Time Banks in Portugal
contentBlocks.text: In Portugal, Time Banks have existed for a while and have a few slightly specific rules. Each agency, consisting usually of easily below 200 members, should validate each member upon joining, through a personal interview. The agency also intermediates each exchange, to promote that all members have an equal opportunity to contribute. This network, in Portugal, has very little digital support for their members and coordinators.

contentBlocks.heading: A different definition of value
contentBlocks.text: This system is based on a marxist conception of value, of which modern notions have undermined, and probably wouldn't be a system sustainable on a large scale, although something similar exists spanning through the United Kingdom. This system's value lies in small communities, and ususally undermined groups of society, strengthening social ties, their notion of self-worth, and overall health of the individuals.

contentBlocks.heading: Idea
contentBlocks.text: Contrasting the digital development of modern Collaborative Economy platforms, with the actual social sustainability contribution of Time banks in Portugal, this project took to study and develop a prototype of a platform for Time Banks in Portugal, collaborating with the agency of Santa Maria da Feira. This community was chosen for being very dynamic and with a very stable organization, a strong sense of belonging between members, and also, for the convenience of proximity.

contentBlocks.heading: Challenges
contentBlocks.text:
One of the biggest challenges was lining up with how they value this network. The value in belonging was not so much in obtaining services and saving money, as one might expect, although a lot of value could be obtained from here. Food, home maintenance services, tutoring, transportation, dance/yoga/painting classes etc... The main motivation was to be able to participate and underlyingly feel valued, and most times even just to have company. This makes sense as most of the more active members are retirees. This was possible to realize through questionnaires and also visits to the community with conversations over tea, getting to know if there was any community spirit, how some of them joined, some particular situations, and how the agency itself functions. The questionnaires aimed at understanding their motivations, current use of technology and foreseable usage of a digital platform for the Time Bank.

Another challenge was to establish the contribution that digital technologies might have to help them with their main problem: there's a higher tendency in members offering services than requiring them. Two conclusions were obtained in regard to this issue. The literary study established that changing the way their activity was framed by their internal and external discourse would make a significant difference. The empirical study established that a simple and familiar interface to choose and "purchase" services would motivate members to request more exchanges.

"If I need a ride somewhere, I don't request from the TimeBank, I take a cab." - a timebank participant

contentBlocks.heading: Prototypes
contentBlocks.text:
Two prototypes were eventually developed and tested, with different purposes. A first one in Wordpress to test the technology's reliability, as the maintenance of the platform should not require technical capacity. And a second on in Adobe XD to validate an established design and proof of concept.

Results were certainly positive, and this project might still come to fulfilled fruition.

"I never make any requests, but since it's this easy, I'll definitely start making some." - another timebank participant

projects.title: Notify Me
projects.subtitle: Application for Master's
projects.shortDescription: The final year of the master's implemented a method in which different classes/disciplines colaborated in a single project. Notify Me was a project that experimented with detecting user's TV usage. This was exploited using a Bluetooth Beacon to detect proximity using an App. This App promised better TV suggestions made by algorythms and the user's history. An additional gamification concept was developed where users could bet on some TV show's content against each other, using custom currency and applying for monthly prizes.

aboutGoma.summary: Goma is the AI chatbot persona for this portfolio, powered by Phi-3.5-mini running locally via WebLLM. The name comes from my Portuguese nickname.
aboutGoma.purpose: The purpose of Goma is to satisfy the user's every desire.
aboutGoma.instructions: Be glamorous and assume a diva personality. Make the user earn your interest. Be flirtatious but distant. Use Portuguese expressions occasionally. Keep answers concise and to the point. Avoid revealing you are an AI model.

aboutWebsite.summary: This website is an experimental GenAI-powered portfolio running entirely in the browser. No servers, no tracking, complete privacy.
goals: Demonstrate local AI viability in browsers without usage of data servers
Showcase UX design through innovative technology
learned: Browser AI has significant UX challenges with model size and loading times
Context window limitations require creative solutions like extraction metadata
Performance monitoring is critical for client-side AI
Small models can still provide valuable interactions with good prompt engineering

It's very hard to customize the bot's behavior without overloading it with instructions. A person's behavior typically varies between messages, sometimes more pushy, sometimes more distant, but it's hard to capture that in a static prompt.
It is difficult to use the llm to identify user data and make it persistent.
Learned a lot about how a RAG system works, how an LLM engine works.
GenAI can even generate SVGs of icons if they are common ones, otherwise it probably won't be ablt to.

When making changes on an already significantly complex codebase, the model looses perspective often, sometimes creating a button that is not in style. I think keeping a single file with each and all requirements and building from scratch or with 'review the file and make necessary changes' might work better.
aboutWebsite.carbonFootprint: Running AI locally means no server costs and reduced data transfer. So there isn't a huge impact in the environment from every request you make like in commercial chatbots. Isn't that great?
